As we begin #WomensHistoryMonth 2020, we are so very #CVproud to share photos from a special event held this morning. A Cumberland Valley High School junior, Maggie Shaver-Wilson, has designed artwork to grace the back of five CAT buses that travel throughout the region. The artwork focuses on Claudette Colvin, a teenage civil rights activist in 1955 who, like Rosa Parks would do nine months later, refused to give up her seat on a bus that was transporting her home from High School. Colvin‚Äôs story is the subject of a book, Claudette Colvin: Twice Toward Justice.

The effort to showcase the student artwork and to recognize Claudette Colvin was spearheaded by CV High School‚Äôs Cassie McKenzie, a student in our History & Literature of Black Civil Rights class, who reached out to CAT officials and worked together to coordinate the project.

The student artwork was formally unveiled this morning at Cumberland Valley High School in a ceremony that featured remarks from students, staff, and Capital Area Transit officials.

Cumberland Valley High School proudly presents Almost, Maine, beginning at 7 p.m. on November 23 and 2 p.m. on November 24 in the Performing Arts Center.

Almost, Maine is a series of slightly connected love stories, each with a fascinating couple at its center, each with its own touch of aurora borealis mystical energy. A woman carries her heart, broken into pieces in a small paper bag everywhere she goes. A man shrinks after losing hope in love. A couple keeps the love they have given each other in large sack or bags the size of a diamond. One deeply cold and magical winter night, these couples of the town of Almost, Maine ‚Äì not big enough for a town, too big for a wilderness ‚Äì come face-to-face with the life-altering power of the human heart. Relationships end, begin, or change beyond recognition.
